p: Despite the great diversity of bacterial species in the oral cavity, few are able to cause tooth decay (cariogenic bacteria) and S. mutans has been implicated as the major etiological agent of this oral infectious disease [ 13]. The cariogenic potential displayed by this bacterium is due to its ability to produce acid (acidogenic) from dietary carbohydrate, capacity to survive in low-pH environments (aciduric) and, especially, due to its great ability to adhere onto the tooth surfaces, which makes S. mutans responsible for the initial formation of dental plaque [ 14].
